#Text=2. Materials and Methods
#Text=A Euler – Lagrangian approach was adopted to represent the two-phase flow .
#Text=Herein , a full inter-phase two-way coupling was accounted for .
#Text=Carrier gas-phase quantities were interpolated into droplets positions , while influences of the dispersed phase were introduced through source terms in computational cells .
#Text=2.1.
#Text=Gas Phase
#Text=The turbulent motions of the carrier phase are described in the LES context following a variable-density low Mach number formulation .
#Text=According to this approach , mass and momentum equations are described by ( 1 ) ( 2 )
#Text=The dependent filtered variables were obtained from spatial filtering as with .
#Text=Over-bars and tildes express spatially filtered and density-weighted filtered values with a filter width , respectively , while double prime represents sub-grid scale ( SGS ) fluctuations .

#Text=is the mixture density , t time , components of velocity in j ( ) direction , p pressure , Cartesian coordinate in j direction , the dynamic viscosity , the component of gravitational acceleration , the Kronecker ’s delta , and the strain rate .
#Text=The term corresponds to the introduction of mass from the droplets into the carrier phase , while is the source term of momentum due to the presence of the dispersed phase .
#Text=Both follow the implementations presented by Chrigui et al. .
#Text=The SGS stress tensor is closed by means of the Smagorinsky model with the dynamic procedure of Germano et al. .
#Text=More details about the mathematical treatment given here to mass and momentum equations can be found in Sacomano Filho et al. .
#Text=2.1.1. Mixture Formation and Combustion Modeling

#Text=In order to account for the evaporative cooling and general heat exchanges , three scalar quantities are used to characterize the mixture following the FGM method : the mixture fraction Z , the reaction progress variable , and the absolute enthalpy of the gas mixture h .
#Text=The transport equation for them can be written in terms of a general variable within the ATF modeling as ( 3 ) where is the turbulent viscosity .

#Text=For the transport equations of Z and , and respectively represent the laminar and the turbulent Schmidt numbers ( ) , while for h both respectively correspond to the laminar and the turbulent Prandtl numbers ( ) .
#Text=It is important to highlight that , with these values for and the unitary approach is maintained .
#Text=The quantity F corresponds to the thickening factor , to the efficiency function , and denotes the flame sensor .
#Text=Details about these quantities are addressed below .
#Text=The term corresponds to the reaction rate for the whereas it is set to zero for the mixture fraction and absolute enthalpy equation .
#Text=Similarly to the reaction progress variable source term , and are obtained from the employed FGM table .
#Text=Therefore , these are expressed as functions of the transported scalar quantities Z , , and h .
#Text=The source term consists of the source of vapor introduced by the dispersed phase in the transport equation for Z , specifically .

#Text=Considering that the mass fraction of fuel is not present in the combination used to define the reaction progress variable ( see Equation ( 15 ) ) , as well as no isolated droplet burning model is included in the employed approach , does not contribute ( therefore it is set to zero ) for the transport of .

#Text=For the transport equation of h , is given by ( 4 ) where denotes the mass of vapor released by the parcel p into the control volume V , is the droplet mass , the number of real droplets in parcel p , N

#Text=the total number of tracked parcels , the specific sensible heat of liquid , a reference temperature ( 298 K ) , the droplet temperature at time step , the formations enthalpy , and the heat of vaporization .
#Text=More description about how the phase coupling source terms are computed in the ATF context can be found in .
#Text=Following the ATF method , the flame thickening is performed by means of a dynamic procedure .
#Text=Accordingly , only the flame region is thickened and no interferences of the ATF with the pre-vaporization zone occur .
#Text=The flame sensor used by Aschmoneit to simulate partially premixed flames is employed here .
#Text=The quantity in Equation ( 5 ) is associated to the maximum value of the source term at the same mixture composition and enthalpy level . ( 5 )
#Text=where is the flame sensor proposed by Durand and Polifke as implemented in .
#Text=In this context , a progress variable in its normalized form is needed , which is defined as .
#Text=Herein , denotes the equilibrium value of for a specific mixture composition .
